page.title: 06OXENBOURNE NATURE RESERVE
page.content: An area of unimproved chalk grassland, thorn scrubs and mature yews,managed by the Hants C.C.and I.O.W.Naturalists Trust,designated as a site of special scientific interest.It is rich in flora.Orchids are abundant.Mosses and lichens are being studied.Butterflies abound.Most important is the Duke of Burgandy Fritillary which feeds on cowslips.Because of the many insects, especially a wasp unknown elsewhere in England,it is declared a site of entomological importance.Fieldfares and redwings feed on berries in the autumn and whitethroats nest in the summer.Exotic golden pheasants, escapees from captivity,have colonized the woods.Roedeer are seen feeding in the mornings and evenings.It is important to preserve this area for future generations.
